answer_html: As d is given to be 77, and 77 has only the prime factors 7 and 11, we see that there can only be two nontrivial terms in the expansion of d.Thus only two of these divisors can be prime.
answer_latex:
As \emph{d} is given to be 77, and 77 has only
the prime factors 7 and 11, we see that there can only be two nontrivial
terms in the expansion of \emph{d}.Thus only two of these divisors can
be prime.
hints_html:
Start off by using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

\(\displaystyle n = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\)

How can we write the number of divisors of n in this notation?
hints_latex:
Start off by using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

$\displaystyle n = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}$

How can we write the number of divisors of \emph{n} in this notation?
hints_raw:
Start off by using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

<math>
\displaystyle n = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}
</math>

How can we write the number of divisors of ''n'' in this notation?
sols_html:
Start off by using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

\(\displaystyle n = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}\)

Then the number of divisors of n is

\(\displaystyle d = \prod_{i=1}^{n}(\alpha_{i}+1)\)

To see this, notice that each prime factor has \(\displaystyle \alpha_{i} +1\) choices of occurring in the divisor of n (either you do not select the divisor or you select the divisor and some power of it). As d is given to be 77, and 77 has only the prime factors 7 and 11, we see that there can only be two nontrivial terms in the expansion of d. Thus only two of these divisors can be prime.
sols_latex:
Start off by using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

$\displaystyle n = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}$

Then the number of divisors of \emph{n} is

$\displaystyle d = \prod_{i=1}^{n}(\alpha_{i}+1)$

To see this, notice that each prime factor has
$\displaystyle \alpha_{i} +1$ choices of occurring in the divisor of
\emph{n} (either you do not select the divisor or you select the divisor
and some power of it). As \emph{d} is given to be 77, and 77 has only
the prime factors 7 and 11, we see that there can only be two nontrivial
terms in the expansion of \emph{d}. Thus only two of these divisors can
be prime.
sols_raw:
Start off by using the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic to write

<math>
\displaystyle n = \prod_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{\alpha_{i}}
</math>

Then the number of divisors of ''n'' is

<math>
\displaystyle d = \prod_{i=1}^{n}(\alpha_{i}+1)
</math>

To see this, notice that each prime factor has <math> \displaystyle \alpha_{i} +1 </math> choices of occurring in the divisor of ''n'' (either you do not select the divisor or you select the divisor and some power of it). As ''d'' is given to be 77, and 77 has only the prime factors 7 and 11, we see that there can only be two nontrivial terms in the expansion of ''d''. Thus only two of these divisors can be prime.
statement_html: Suppose a positive integer n has 77 positive divisors (1 and n count among them). How many of these divisors can be prime? Explain your answer.
statement_latex:
Suppose a positive integer \emph{n} has 77 positive divisors (1 and
\emph{n} count among them). How many of these divisors can be prime?
Explain your answer.
statement_raw: Suppose a positive integer ''n'' has 77 positive divisors (1 and ''n'' count among them). How many of these divisors can be prime? Explain your answer.
